item.title: Linear Transformations, Change of Basis and Image Compression
item.description: 27.1 Linear Transformations When we are dealing with coordinates, every linear transformation leads us to a matrix. For any vector $v$ and $w$, linear transformation $T$ follows following properties: $T(v+w) = T(v) + T(w)$ $T(cv) = cT(v)$ $T(0) = T(0)$, derived from tha above two properties Below are some examples and non-examples of linear transformation: Example 1: Projection In a two-dimensional space $\mathbb{R}^2$, a projection of a vector $v$ on a line is linear transformation and can be denoted as $T:\mathbb{R}^2 \to \mathbb{R}^2$.
